blog/bart-homeomorphism.title: Homeomorphisms, Invariants, and BART; oh my!
blog/bart-homeomorphism.content:
intro! and what this post aims to do
This is a hand hold-y article. This is meant to build intuition around a topic that can be very very complex and can often leave you battered, weak, and frail. I aim not to do that! In fact, basically the whole article is:
(Though there ended up being much cool stuff here, so may be worth it for you to come back to later.)
Instead, I hope to give a single, small kernel of truth that is actually used in higher level mathematics, but also simple enough that you‚Äôve already used it in your life and will become one of those things you can‚Äôt unsee (as those are the easiest ideas to build on top of üëº)
I‚Äôd like to do this by:

showing how this neat mathe-magical tool is already working and helping you in your own life
how this same tool is used by higher level mathematicians to solve hairy problems
ideally while keeping it NON-ANXIETY INDUCING and actually pretty simple (along with some historical context and ‚Äòsmell the flowers‚Äô tidbits)

~ Off we go!! ~
MATH and BART
San Fransisco is pretty cool. We have public transit (and maps of it)


BART Map #1 (source: curtiswrightmaps.com/wp-content/uploads/map_32.35x24.22_02-27-24_inv005986-scaled.jpg)



Map #2 (source: www.reddit.com/media%3A%2F%2Fpreview.redd.it%2Fe13guqvbrl3c1.jpg%3Fwidth%3D3600%26format%3Dpjpg%26auto%3Dwebp%26s%3D95000fa1edb9c65063980e77eb0edda326478437)

I prefer this one though since it‚Äôs a bit easier to read


Map #3 (source: s.hdnux.com/photos/01/12/00/20/19399708/3/rawImage.jpg)

And here‚Äôs an even further stripped down version of that same map: 

Map #4 (source: www.reddit.com/media%3A%2F%2Fi.redd.it%2Ftk1q3kigp4wc1.png)

There‚Äôs presumably some advantage to having these stripped down maps, but let‚Äôs compare a couple more just to see:
  

Map #5 (left) Map #6 (right)

For both of these, count the number of stops between Pittsburg/Bay Point and Lafayette. One is basically a number line, the other is a trail to traverse. (This may seem tedious, but we‚Äôll be using maps later for a similar reason.)
When you look at any of the squiggly areas of Map 6 (or any of the info heavy maps) it adds some cognitive tax to make sure you haven‚Äôt missed a stop or gotten off track or whatever else; with the straight line you just count the dots and you‚Äôre done.
You can further test this with the previous maps; try counting on map 1 how many stops it is to get from Colma (Red line) to West Dublin/Pleasanton (Blue), El Cerrito del Norte (Red) to Concord (Yellow), or OAK Airport (Grey, right hand side of the Bay) to Glen Park (Red). Actually try one of these examples! It‚Äôs your qualia at stake.
Then, try any of these on map 3 or 4 and at least I feel how much easier it is to locate these things. But why is that?
üéº ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the use?‚Äù üéµ
There‚Äôs basically two things that are happening here:

we remove non-essential info
we retain essential info

Quiz time. While I‚Äôm riding the BART do I need to know:

Q: What mountain ranges (Map 1) are in the Bay to get to SFO? A: Hell no
Q: That North Concord is to the West of Pittsburg/Bay Point? A: HELL no

So we can get rid of that!
But what do you need to keep? You must keep the connections that BART actually makes in real life (like North Berkeley connects directly to Downtown Berkeley in each of the maps and SFO didn‚Äôt magically connect to OAK airport somehow), otherwise the map is now out of touch with reality. KEEP THE CONNECTIVITY.
We can move them in whatever shape we want to, but as long as we don‚Äôt 1. create / destroy stops, or 2. create / destroy connections then we can use it to accurately plan on the BART.
That‚Äôs it!
Concept Exposition
there are math terms concepts hidden here, let‚Äôs make them obvious so we can compare the actual math to our BART example. (don‚Äôt worry too much about knowing EXACTLY what everything means, just make associations)
Homeomorphism (big boi)
When we take one map and change it to another (‚Äúsame‚Äù, but ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù) map, that‚Äôs called a ‚Äúhomeomorphism‚Äù. This can roughly be broken into:

homeo = ‚Äúsame‚Äù
morphism = ‚Äúshape, form, structure‚Äù

‚ÄúSame structure‚Äù == they have the same connections.
We could talk about homeomorphisms by saying ‚ÄúMap 1 and 2 are homeomorphic to each other‚Äù or ‚ÄúMap 2 is a homeomorphic transformation of Map 1‚Äù. And we can say this for all four maps, they‚Äôre all homeomorphic to each other. They‚Äôre all ‚Äúthe same‚Äù in some way (same connections!), but they‚Äôre also all ‚Äúdifferent‚Äù from each other (different shapes and details and stuff).
Invariant:
‚ÄúSame structure‚Äù, but some things are different‚Ä¶but some things are the same? Yes! and those things that stay the same are the ‚Äúinvariants‚Äù because they‚Ä¶don‚Äôt vary. MATHEMATICIAN YOU ARE!
Again, in the case of these maps, what‚Äôs not changing are the connections or the connectivity of said maps. In every map you can get from North Berkeley to Downtown Berkeley, Downtown Berkeley to Union City, Union City to Balboa Park. Since those connections are the same in every map, we can use every map to plan our travel. Invariant!!
Why are these useful to know about?
Practically, look at the maps above and see how some are easier to work with than others.
More specifically, we can change problems and remove information so that they‚Äôre easier to work with, while still having our representations be true. For example, Fermat‚Äôs Last Theorem was unsolved for 350 years, put into a different form and then became possible to solve.

This one looks quite simple, but again it was unsolved for 350 years before someone made it ‚Äúsimple‚Äù enough to be solveable at all. The problem:
‚ÄúFermat‚Äôs Last Theorem states that there are no three positive integers a, b, and c that can satisfy the equation a^n+b^n=c^n for any integer value of n greater than 2. This theorem was first proposed by Pierre de Fermat in 1637 and was famously proven by Andrew Wiles in 1994.‚Äù  (Quote generated by DuckDuckGo with sources: wiki, quanta)

If you‚Äôre already math inclined, U-Substitutions have probably made your life much easier for calculating integrals, using Fourier transforms for signal processing or solving differential equations, and likely countless others.
I‚Äôll hereby designate ‚Äúthese things‚Äù as‚Ä¶
‚ÄùProblem Reformations‚Äù
Just as it sounds, put a problem in a different form and it can sometimes become much easier. Ok!

Just those three things will carry us through: Homeomorphisms, invariants, and problem reformations.
‚ÄùYou think that‚Äôs a bridge you‚Äôre crossing?‚Äù


from‚Ä¶Morpheus (who was a homie)


And a quick aside on the Greek God Morpheus, he assumed forms and structures!
"""  According to Ovid ‚Äúno other is more skilled than he in representing the gait, the features‚Ä¶""" -source


""" Ovid called Morpheus and his brothers‚Ä¶the Somnia (‚Äúdream shapes‚Äù), saying that they appear in dreams ‚Äúmimicking many forms‚Äù. """ -source


Back to the math! The simple simple origin lore is that a real smart guy wanted to figure out how to cross some bridges (but only a single time). Ahem:

‚ÄúThe Seven Bridges of K√∂nigsberg is a historically notable problem in mathematics. Its negative resolution by Leonhard Euler, in 1736, laid the foundations of graph theory and prefigured the idea of topology‚Ä¶The problem was to devise a walk through the city that would cross each of those bridges once and only once. ‚Äù -source

The bridges in question:

Now ask, this is a city map‚Ä¶how do you do math on this? That indeed is a difficult question! In fact, ‚ÄúThe difficulty [Euler] faced was the development of a suitable technique of analysis, and of subsequent tests that established this assertion with mathematical rigor. ‚Äù -source
Or in other words, in order to answer this question, he had to create new math techniques to work with it. Not just a simple thing unfortunately! But, the tool that Euler had created is what allows us to take this City Map and turn it into the graph with lines, create a solution based on THAT and trust that our graph solution would still apply to the Bridges of K√∂nigsberg.
‚ÄùBut the map looks pretty simple, why not just trace it out?‚Äù
(Just as a reminder, this probably looked simple too, a^n+b^n=c^n)
And if you were to guess how many possible paths there were, how many would you guess? 20? 500? 20,000? This math.stackexchange user counts it at 372 (but can be reduced to 282), which still sounds hellish! 372 routes and then you find out that it‚Äôs actually impossible to cross any of them only a single time. There‚Äôs no possible route! I‚Äôd feel a bit let down (and then imagine if we didn‚Äôt have math and you had to walk that. Makes you grateful ü´Ç)
On top of that, these bridges are a small graph. Imagine operating on someting like this:


(source: my obsidian vault, nbd)

So how do the tools help solve this?
Again our tools: homeomorphism, invariants, and problem reformations.
Problem Reformation
‚ÄúEuler first pointed out that the choice of route inside each land mass is irrelevant and that the only important feature of a route is the sequence of bridges crossed‚Ä¶This allowed him to [eliminate] all features except the list of land masses and the bridges connecting them.‚Äù -source
As a result he came up with something like this:

(Which we view similarly to our own maps‚Ä¶)
((TODO))
To align our BART maps with Euler AND modern terminology, ‚Äúone replaces each land masses with an abstract ‚Äòvertex‚Äô or node, and each bridge with an abstract connection, an ‚Äòedge‚Äô -source

‚Äúvertex / node‚Äù = land mass = BART stop
‚Äúedge‚Äù                = bridge        = train tracks

The next thing he realizes is that if a node / land mass / green dot has an odd number of connections, then you end up stuck there! Here‚Äôs a visual:


source
note: this is the same as the green dot graph just above, just with numbers and slightly different shaped, but it‚Äôs a homeomorphism of that graph üòú

Looking at one of the ‚Äú3‚Äù nodes, you could cross it once (2/3 bridges crossed; one to get in, one to get out), but then if you visit it again there‚Äôs no path for you to leave from! Not all is lost, if you have two dots with odd numbered connections, you could start at one then end at the other. But! If you were to have more than two of these, you‚Äôd start at one then be stuck at another before you could get to the final; it can‚Äôt work.
‚ÄùThe answer becomes trivial‚Ä¶‚Äù
Seeing this, the answer becomes extremely easy to find:

make a graph
count the connections on each node / dot

this is called the ‚Äúdegree of a node‚Äù, as in ‚Äúthe nodes in the graph above have a degree of 3 and 5‚Äù


count the number of odd degree nodes, if over two, the graph doesn‚Äôt work!

You could even imagine a much bigger graph‚Ä¶


(source: my obsidian vault, nbd)

and creating a program that counts:

how many connections
number of odd degree connections
computes if num_odd_degrees > 2 == False
and then you have it solved. you could chatGPT that pretty quickly.

But how do we know? How can we be sure we didn‚Äôt fudge something?
It‚Äôs much easier to verify for the Bridges problem when there were only four nodes, but my obisdian graph has over 3.5k nodes (nbd), and god only knows how many connections have been made; do we have proof that nothing got lost in the details?
What if we looked at a different graph to see what made it different? Fortunately, it‚Äôs pretty simple, and we‚Äôve already covered it; connectivity from earlier. The graph will be the same as long as you don‚Äôt

create / destroy stops (nodes), or
create / destroy connections (edges)

Because if that doesn‚Äôt happen, how else could the graph change? Here‚Äôs an interactive artifact to play with and ask yourself, ‚Äúis this graph actually changing? do I only care about connectivity?‚Äù
But this is still visual, it‚Äôs not mathy enough. Can we go further? Yes!
Return of the Invariant
First, if these are the same graphs (just moved around):

 

What are the mathematic properties that stay the same? And also, how am I supposed to feed either of these into an algorithm? Feed an image into a number algorithm?
We turn these graphs into data structures; where we can change a map of K√∂nigsberg into this graph, and all of the following will be true for them (again, as long as we don‚Äôt create or destroy the nodes or edges).
Data Structures
1. Adjacency List
Node 0 connects to: [1, 2]
Node 1 connects to: [0, 2, 3]
Node 2 connects to: [0, 1, 3]
Node 3 connects to: [1, 2]

2. Edge List
Edges: (0,1), (0,2), (1,2), (1,3), (2,3)

3. Adjacency Matrix  (1 means connected, 0 means not connected)
    0  1  2  3
0 [ 0  1  1  0 ]
1 [ 1  0  1  1 ]
2 [ 1  1  0  1 ]
3 [ 0  1  1  0 ]

4. Degree Sequence
Node degrees: [2, 3, 3, 2]

5. Incidence Matrix
      e1 e2 e3 e4 e5
Node0 [1  1  0  0  0]
Node1 [1  0  1  1  0]
Node2 [0  1  1  0  1]
Node3 [0  0  0  1  1]

We can also look at an interesting example to see what happens when the graph actually does change, with the same bridges!
When bad graphs go good
In WWII (and various other changes) throughout the years, a couple of the bridges of K√∂nigsberg were destroyed; how did that change the graph? From www.datawrapper.de/blog/euler-bridges-konigsberg, ‚ÄúBut with only five bridges left in K√∂nigsberg, today it is actually possible to find an Euler walk through the city.‚Äù They then show:

Different graph! and with different essential characteristics.
(WORKING IN PUBLIC; WORK IN PROGRESS)

blog/joy-diss.title: The Joy of Cognitive Dissonance
blog/joy-diss.content:
‚ÄúWell, all information looks like noise until you break the code.‚Äù - Neal Stephenson

A mentor described ‚ÄúCognitive Dissonance‚Äù to me as the feeling our brains get when something in our environment doesn‚Äôt fit in with our model of how the world usually operates. In other words, this is an opportunity to learn something.
Putting difficult information in front of you in order to become more capable is mostly done (I would guess) with things like literature or math, but I don‚Äôt suspect people view listening to music in the same way. It‚Äôs often viewed as something to be done for relaxation and something unoffensive and predictable-ish is looked for.
As a musician, this is much less normal and then only way to become a better musician is to push past what you currently know and be willing seek out those concepts that don‚Äôt make sense to you. (I‚Äôd argue that this has benefits past being a better musician, such as being a more empathetic human and being able to understand greater complexities; but that‚Äôs a different article.)
a lil taste of what you can push towards
This is an example that I think is quite perfect. It looks like noise, likely you can‚Äôt make sense of it, but read these instructions and keep in mind that this song only two patterns (one pattern has variations, but still only two patterns).

Listen to this entire song (on a lower volume if it‚Äôs too heavy)

In case further links get taken down, ‚ÄúThe Sentinel‚Äù by Car Bomb


(listen before you go on to the next instruction)
‚Ä¶
‚Ä¶
make sure you‚Äôve listened before you go on to the next instruction!!!
There‚Äôs a guiding pattern throughout the entire song, and it‚Äôs incredibly simple.
Listen again and again to find what it is.
If you give up / want to check your answer, here is the spoiler.

What this reminds me of is looking at a math equation and thinking ‚Äúthis is an absolute mess‚Äù until you look at it long enough and everything fits into place and specifically, it‚Äôs odd to you that it didn‚Äôt make sense in the first place.
For me, when I see a pattern like this and make sense of it, I can‚Äôt stop raving about it it‚Äôs so exciting. That one simple pattern being adjusted in simple simple ways created such a complex piece of work (at least, it appears as so). To me, this is the joy of cognitive dissonance; where you are hit with tension, but when the release hits‚Ä¶it‚Äôs a beautiful thing.
(Post note for nerds, this band is way into G√∂del, Escher, Bach according to their Wikipedia)

blog/master-as-the-needle.title: master as the needle - blog series
blog/master-as-the-needle.content:
intro and motivation


I don‚Äôt feel accomplished when I vibe code, ‚Äúhe who does the work gets the learning‚Äù and if I outsource all / most of it then I‚Äôm not actually becoming a more capable person when I have Claude write all my code, and I think that‚Äôs not good.


Instead, I had the thought that I can LLM‚Äôs to write code for my projects, get something that works, then go back through and come to understand why the code is working and what it‚Äôs doing under the hood.


Relatedly, I‚Äôve seen some job applications that say they‚Äôre fine with people using AI tools to write code in interviews, but the interviewer will also test whether the applicant actually understands what‚Äôs being written. If that‚Äôs a make or break it, then I‚Äôd like to prevent myself from breaking it, which is also helpful if the LLM isn‚Äôt able to replace programmers yet; you may need to visit the trenches from time to time!


And so, I decided I would 1. use LLM‚Äôs to (help) create different projects I‚Äôm working on and 2. go back through to understand what it was that made the code work at all. Ideally, this should make me a better developer as well, in the least to understand on an intuitive level and be able to use that to better prompt models in the future.


In the ‚ÄúBook of Five Rings‚Äù, Miyamoto Musashi mentions the phrase ‚ÄúThe master as the needle, the student as the thread.‚Äù As I‚Äôd never heard this before, I looked around and the best explanation I found was saying how:

The master will guide the student through the terrain of the problem (like a needle)
But the student has to do the actual work by providing the strength needed for a solution to work (like the thread).

the master will no longer be necessary, but the student remains while keeping the structure together.





In this way, I become the thread and come out on the other side understanding better how the machine works.


This is a series of experiments in this vein where I‚Äôll detail how I built different projects and what I learned in the post-mortem, complete with prompts, facts, and other tidbits that will help your own journey.


the solution relies on the strength of the student to support the residual structure
the master as the needle
‚ÄúTell me and I‚Äôll forget, show me I‚Äôll remember, involve me and I‚Äôll understand.‚Äù
There‚Äôs a critical line between technological capability and genuine understanding, can you truly comprehend something without wrestling with its complexity? The phrase ‚Äòthose who do the work receive the learning‚Äô is more than a platitude; it‚Äôs a commitment to technologically influenced thinking, where AI becomes a tool for insight, not a replacement for understanding.
the core learning strategy
My approach is simple, and deliberate: use LLMs to generate working code for projects, and then dive deep to understand why and how that code works under the hood.
In the ‚ÄúBook of Five Rings‚Äù, Miyamoto Musashi mentions the phrase ‚ÄúThe master as the needle, the student as the thread.‚Äù The consensus I‚Äôve found on what this means goes:

The master guides the student through the terrain of a problem (like a needle)
The student provides solution and uses their strenth to support it (like the thread)
Ultimately, the master becomes unnecessary, but the student remains, holding the structure together

In this way, I aim to have LLMs be my needle and have myself become the thread, learning to support the structures I‚Äôm working with.
what to expect in this series
This blog series is an experiment in active, intentional learning. Each post will be a deep dive into a specific project:

How the project was conceived
Initial AI-assisted code generation
Code review with detailed exploration of key concepts
Personal reflections and learning moments
Practical insights for other learners

This series is a live experiment in understanding; deliberately messy, intentionally iterative, and perpetually evolving. Not to continually be seeking perfection, but instead persistent curiosity.

blog/morphisms.title: understanding sprint - morphisms
blog/morphisms.content:
Purpose of this document

I‚Äôve seen the root ‚Äúmorph‚Äù around quite a bit and it has scared me and as all good parties go, last night I was insctructed in the ways of homomorphic encryption and when looking at the wikipdia page I traced back to morphisms and thought it looked too fun to pass up.
What this document will be a brain dump of me trying to figure out these main concepts; sense making of morphisms. Interested to see if this is helpful to anyone else (I got feedback on a programming project where I typed out my thoughts of how to solve different problems and they said it was an interesting peak into my mind, I hope you enjoy)
This isn‚Äôt intended to be ‚Äúwell thought‚Äù, this is seeking understanding from what it is I currently know and probably won‚Äôt look ‚Äúvery intelligent‚Äù, that‚Äôs not my intention. I want to learn what Morphisms are and will ramble my way to understanding

Musings

‚Äústructure preserving map‚Äù

structure preserving, I thought about compression and figured that must be keeping the ‚Äúformation‚Äù in ‚Äúinformation‚Äù, structure preserving.

which is interesting to think about; you can preserve some ‚Äústructure‚Äù by changing its representation with a key and instructions of where the keys are put back into. The structure is in a different form, but it still retains a structure in common with the thing from before.


map ‚áí homie;


‚Äúfrom one structure to another one of the same type‚Äù

a mapping from one structure to another of the same type that preserves its inherent structure
that‚Äôs so flexible. maybe having a structure in some form is easier for processing in particular ways

ohhhh the homomorphic encryption mentioned that it ‚Äúallows computation to be performed on encrypted data without having to decrypt it‚Äù
so you‚Äôre putting the structure (which is your sensitive data?) in a different form, but it retains its inherent properties. Interesting.




oh my god I already recognize some of this stuff:

‚Äúin linear algebra, linear transformations‚Äù; that makes this seem way simpler.
‚Äúin set theory, morphisms are functions‚Äù; I don‚Äôt know set theory but when I see f(x) = x^2, I see there‚Äôs an equal sign; I‚Äôm not totally confident in that.
// side note, I see set, group, and category theory fairly often to be interested in them‚Ä¶


category theory is ?heavily based? on morphisms and the structures (‚Äúobjects‚Äù) that they‚Äôre defined for?
under ‚ÄúDefinition‚Äù heading says ‚Äúa category C‚Äù, must be big on it.

so what does that say about category theory? that structures are central to it? hmmm


I like this definiton of terms, this is great.

So in this thing that people call a ‚Äúcategory‚Äù you can expect roughly two types of things to be seen, 1. objects, and 2. morphisms. When you look at the objects there‚Äôs going to be two types called the source and the target.
One way to think of this is if you had two objects catapillar and butterfly and a morphism called weird-cocoon-thing you could say this is math terms like: a morphism "weird - cocoon - thing" from "catapillar" to "butterfly"
ok, so there‚Äôs probably a whole bunch of morphisms in a single category, do they apply to each combo of source target?


many common categories, the objects are sets. so you perform functions on sets.

codomain, that‚Äôs a cool word, like codo main


wow compositions

morphisms have this operation, you need two morphisms

(( I really like this understanding of coding in the background; this ^^ just kinda fits into that ))


take morphism target m and source n and write it like n \circ m.

but a weird thing, if you to find the source of n \circ m, you would take the ‚Äúsource of the target‚Äù (the target being morphism m, so take the source of whatever you feed to m)
and if you want to find the target of n \circ m, then you would take the target of the source (the source being morphism n, and take whatever target is being used there). Weird. I wonder why that is. I wonder if it was just defined that way

I still don‚Äôt get why the target of your source morphism is the source of the composition. That‚Äôs confusing to me. Where‚Äôs the love for the outside morphisms? üôÅ






‚Äúthe composition satisifies two axioms‚Äù; satisfies two axioms, what does that mean? did the axioms come first? satisfies them. hmmm

but I feel like I heard the identity elsewhere, maybe linear algebra

identity matrix?


why do you need the identity morphism? what‚Äôs its purpose? It must do something otherwise it wouldn‚Äôt be worth mentioning. are these included in all categories, or for each object in a category?

this has to do with compositions, so maybe that‚Äôs the key


I‚Äôm skipping this for now. confusing.


oh remember, associativity is not communicativity (or that thing close to this word)

which is confusing because there is the associativity axiom and the coomutative diagrams. need to get that straight.


concrete category, don‚Äôt quiiiite get what makes these disticnt from regular categories (it must have some rules, it inherets from categories, and then has some other stuff)


god I love diagrams that are easy. simple mind ftw
these are called ‚Äúcommutative diagrams‚Äù.
if I had to guess what something like h \circ g \circ f would look like it would be



flowchart TD
    A -->|f| B
    B -->|g| C 
    C -->|h| D
    
    A -->|h ‚àò g ‚àò f| D


why is this important? What‚Äôs so special about identity huh?

it is nice that this ^^ article is short.



Side travel to homomorphisms

‚Äúhomomorphisms of vector spaces are called linear maps, and their study is the subject of linear algebra‚Äù

neat


This is interesting: ‚Äúthe conept of homomorphism has been generalized‚Ä¶to many other structures‚Ä¶This generalizaion is the starting point of category theory.‚Äù

homomorph was the first?


oh beautiful, ‚Äúa homomorphism is a mpa between two algebraic structures of the same type that preserves the operations of the structures.‚Äù

preserving operations, and that‚Äôs what makes this perfect for encryption doesn‚Äôt it? Oh that‚Äôs so beautiful


registering (but not following interest now), I saw the word ‚Äúfunctor‚Äù on (I htink) the morphism wiki, and I remember seeing the word ‚Äúendofunctor‚Äù, possibly in the rust language. I wonder how morphisms tie into the language (if they do)

wait, and now I‚Äôm seeing monoids, I feel like I‚Äôve seen that before


this sentence could use rewriting

This means a map f : A ‚Üí B between two sets A, B equipped with the same structure such that, if ‚ãÖ is an operation of the structure (supposed here, for simplification, to be a binary operation), then
f ( x ‚ãÖ y ) = f ( x ) ‚ãÖ f ( y )
for every pair x, y . One says often that f preserves the operation or is compatible with the operation.


‚Äúa map between monoids that preserves the monoid operation and not the identity element, is not a monoid homomorphism, but only a semigroup homomorphism.‚Äù

so is a semigroup just a monoid without an identity element?


oh interesting, notation between homomorphed objects desn‚Äôt need to transfer, just the operations.
a couple of the examples of homomorphism says that there are structures made (ring, group) ‚Äúunder‚Äù some operations (‚Äúmatrix addition and multiplication‚Äù, and ‚Äúmultiplication‚Äù respectively)
bijective, surjective, injective‚Ä¶all of these
I feel love reading this stuff. It‚Äôs really difficult and seems like a great challenge. That‚Äôs so nice.
babe hold up, ‚ÄúHomomorphisms are also used in the study of formal languages‚Äù, oh my

damn, immediately lost me



Conclusion

I didn‚Äôt type out very much of this, it felt pretty cumbersome tbh. It was nicer to think about the structures than it was to explain them or voice my thinkings.
in general, this does leave me with a few different takeaways:

I think I‚Äôve got the basic understandings of what people are talking about when they‚Äôre speaking about morphisms. (I remember at one point thinking people could be pompous using terms like ‚Äúisometric‚Äù to describe somethings (actually I still think that because they could‚Äôve exaplained it in simpler terms) but I also recognize that this seems like a flexible tool to work with, and I have some baseline appreciation of the concepts and would enjoy reading more about this stuff)
It was really cool to read about this and also find some terms that had popped up in other contexts (possible programming overlap)
programming and thinking about objects (I think, I‚Äôm not super confident about this) has made it feel somewhat easier to think about these math terms. Thinking about stuff in terms of operations, arguments, structures that are created which have certain characteristics

eg: a category having objects and morphisms. reminds me of somewhat of creating a class where you define methods and have things that you operate on. Felt easy to think in


I love looking at this stuff. Maybe progrmaming is the avenue that will make the math things I‚Äôm interested in a useful pursuit. That would be so cool to work with math structures in this way. Powerful tools.


all in all, it‚Äôs now 16:31:29, and so spent 3 hours reading all of this. and I had a great time. I won‚Äôt say that I understand all minutia about morphisms (lol) but I think I understand enough to see it as art, and that‚Äôs a win.

blog/universality-of-dispatch-worker.title: universality-of-dispatch-worker
blog/universality-of-dispatch-worker.content:
patterns, patterns all around!
In a chaotic group chat I‚Äôm in, someone linked to the Sonic the Headgehog protein. Very cool name, appreciative that people who look at the brain also look at fast blue sprites and decided to combine the two üôè further, a screenshot to Robotnikinin was posted and mentioned this: """ A potential inhibitor of the Hedgehog signaling pathway has been found and dubbed ‚ÄúRobotnikinin‚Äù‚Äîafter Sonic the Hedgehog‚Äôs nemesis and the main antagonist of the Sonic the Hedgehog game series, Dr. Ivo ‚ÄúEggman‚Äù Robotnik. """ -source. we love Dr. Eggman
I‚Äôm not into biology at all, but saw the phrase ‚Äúsignaling pathway‚Äù and thought ‚Äúthat should just be a pathway‚Ä¶for chemicals? maybe this is a simple enough concept that I could get it even with no biology background. And I have a feeling this is similar to a software pattern I was reading about‚Äù (yesterday I had been reading about serverless architectures)
I ask Claude‚Ä¶


ME: I‚Äôm curious what a ‚Äúsignaling pathway‚Äù is in very very simple terms without the use of analogies. I‚Äôm curious if there‚Äôs an analogy to how the dispatch / worker pattern works in SWE, where there‚Äôs some signal that tells another thing to act but isn‚Äôt actually doing the work itself. what do you think?


Claude: A signaling pathway is a sequence of biochemical events where molecules communicate information to coordinate cellular activities. In the most basic terms: molecules send signals that trigger responses in other molecules, creating a chain of communication that ultimately affects what a cell does.
You‚Äôre spot on with the dispatch/worker pattern analogy! In fact, it‚Äôs quite similar.


SWEEEET. and to make sure I understand this fully, I quiz myself:


ME: quiz time! please grade me on this and let me know if I‚Äôm not understanding anything correctly.
basically this is a setup of at least two entities, 1. the dispatch, decides to pass another message along to a different entity, its work stops there. 2. the worker, who receives that message (instructions of what to do), and then executes those instructions. is that correct?


Claude: Grade: A- üéâ
You‚Äôve got the core concept absolutely right! Your understanding of the basic dispatch/worker pattern in signaling pathways is spot-on.
What you nailed: ‚úÖ Two main entities (dispatcher and worker)
‚úÖ Dispatcher‚Äôs job ends after sending the message
‚úÖ Worker receives instructions and executes them
‚úÖ Clear separation of responsibilities
Small refinement for full credit: The one tiny detail is that in biological signaling, there are often multiple workers responding to the same dispatcher. One signaling cell can release SHH that affects many target cells in the surrounding area.


Very cool! It‚Äôs nice when knowing one pattern lessens the burden on learning future patterns. But I didn‚Äôt want to stop there, I had a feeling if this pattern was independently used in two fairly unrelated fields, maybe it‚Äôs also in others? apparently it is!
asked Claude to look for other examples of this pattern and provide a write up (linked to below), but what I liked most about this was a general takeaway it mentions of where this pattern is most useful;


Claude: This pattern‚Äôs ubiquity suggests it‚Äôs a fundamental organizational principle for coordinating complex systems - appearing in everything from cellular biology to global economics. The terminology varies, but the core structure remains remarkably consistent across all these domains!



Finally, I asked Claude to write up a report of:

the initial pattern (maybe as displayed by SWE)
connecting it to the signal pathway in biology
connecting those two together, then
introducing these other systems and outlining how each of them follow this pattern (and ideally with some sort of table that shows how each of these fulfill this pattern).
the benefits and negatives of using this pattern



I didn‚Äôt know about cell signaling! Tying back to Robotnikinin and it being an inhibitor, this mechanism makes a bit more sense (signal needs to be delievered, is being blocked), and makes me also appreciate that they named this inhibitor Sonic‚Äôs nemesis to reflect that relationship. Neat!


conclusion

One of my biggest takeaways from this: ‚ÄúThe pattern‚Äôs success across biological evolution, human organizations, and engineered systems indicates it may be a universal principle of complex system organization‚Äîappearing wherever systems need to coordinate multiple autonomous agents toward common goals.‚Äù
What a fun thing! Decided to click on a small piece that I thought I might come away with (signaling pathways) but ended up learning about complex system organization and a series of examples where this pattern arises (including Dr. Eggman!)
here‚Äôs the link to the report, and the full chat thread.

blog/zk-proof-intro.title: quick thoughts on zk proof foundations
blog/zk-proof-intro.content:
~~ A friendly exploration of zero-knowledge proof basics through dialogue ~~ 
Intro
I like holding hands. This is a hand-holding post on the basic ideas of what makes zero-knowledge proofs work.
Dialogue
Person A: So like, what are they?
Person B: Zero knowledge proof (ZKP), it‚Äôs a way to convince another person that something is true, but you don‚Äôt need to show proof of it (or to have ‚Äúzero knowledge‚Äù of what makes something true).
Person A: What?
Person B: Yeah I know.
Person A: But how?
Person B: Well to start, I think that (with ZKP‚Äôs) saying that ‚ÄúI have proof this is true!‚Äù is actually a bad word to use. We don‚Äôt have proof! Instead, it‚Äôs better to say ‚Äúthis thing is probably true‚Äù.
Person A: ‚Ä¶

‚ö†Ô∏è Key Concept
Zero-knowledge proofs are about probability, not absolute certainty.

Person B: Quick background; there‚Äôs two people in this equation, a prover (the one saying ‚Äúbelieve me!‚Äù) and the verifier (the one saying, ‚Äúbut how do I actually know?‚Äù). The prover wants the verifier to believe them, but doesn‚Äôt want to give out some type of information. (let‚Äôs just say the prover doesn‚Äôt want to share their birthdate, but wants to go a club; they need to prove that they‚Äôre over 21.)
Person A: Ok, prover needs to prove that they‚Äôre over 21, but doesn‚Äôt want to show their birthday.
Person B: Yup. Keep in mind that your proof will either equal ‚Äútrue or false‚Äù (like, you‚Äôre over 21 or not)
Person A: Great
Person B: Great
Person A: But wait, proof = true or false, but you said it‚Äôs better to say ‚Äúprobably true‚Äù?
Person B: Ya, so what happens with some fancy computer magic is the verifier (the one saying ‚Äúcan I actually believe the prover?‚Äù) will give a bunch of True/False tests to the prover. These tests basically say (in computer terms) ‚Äúok, if you actually were over 21, then you should pass this random test!‚Äù The prover can now 1. either guess correctly each time (which sounds hard to do maybe), or they 2. actually are over 21 and you can pass the test.
Person A: But wouldn‚Äôt the answer just be ‚Äúyes‚Äù each time? That seems pretty easy to hack
Person B: Yeah that would, so they change it up a bit. But basically, if you have the ground truth, that you are over 21, it‚Äôs easy to answer correctly. If you don‚Äôt, you just have to guess. You have to guess right every time they ask you a question
Person A: üò≤üòØüòÆ
Person B: ‚ÄºÔ∏èü§Øüòµ
Person A: Each time?
Person B: Ya, imagine having to guess correctly a whole bunch of times, and if you mess up once, you‚Äôre done kiddo. And these guys like math, here‚Äôs how you calculate the probability:

üìä The Math of Certainty
With each additional test, the probability of successfully guessing drops dramatically:

1 test: 50% chance of guessing correctly
2 tests: 25% chance
3 tests: 12.5% chance
And so on‚Ä¶


Person A: Oh my
Person B: And this is also where ‚Äúprobably true‚Äù comes in. If someone guessed it right once, that‚Äôs only 50% chance (true/false). But what if they had to get it right twice? That‚Äôs 25% (50% x 50%). Three times? 12.5%.
Person A: And it just keeps going down?
Person B: Yup, put into your calculator (1/2)^{the number of tests you‚Äôd give}. (first try the above numbers, noting that you have to move the decimal two places to the right to get percentages like above. (1/2)^1 = .5 , but move it two and you‚Äôve got 50%)
Intermission!!
You should actually plug some numbers into the calculator to see how quickly the number goes down. Ask yourself this, if you were the verifier, what would your acceptable percentage be? How small of a chance would you accept of some rando correctly guessing each of your tests? How small does it have to be to accept that guessing correctly probably didn‚Äôt happen?
Back to the show
Person A: Wow, ten tests gives a 0.0976562% of someone guessing correctly, or 1/1024 chance of getting it right.
Person B: Crazy right!? And now again imagine yourself as the verifier (the person checking IDs). At what percentage do you say that you‚Äôre convinced? Is a 9% possibility that a person is lying an ‚Äúacceptable risk to take? The actual percentage is something fun to think about, but the more important thing is to realize that the verifier actually never sees the evidence of whether or not someone is lying, but instead the verifier sees a low enough probability that they‚Äôre not lying and then they are convinced that there‚Äôs no lying taking place. And also, if you‚Äôre not satisfied, you can just ask for more tests (it just takes a bit longer for the calculations to be checked).
Person A: Ohhhhh

üí° The Zero-Knowledge Part
The verifier becomes convinced without ever seeing the actual proof or private information!

Person B: Yeahhhhhhh. And just to wrap it up: the verifier never actually knows that the prover is telling the truth (this is a zero knowledge proof). The verifier is just convinced at some point that the prover is telling the truth.
